Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Metal-Coordination Crosslinked Polymer Networks as Elastomers
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This research in a primarily undergraduate institution (RUI award) is focused on the development of a new type of polymeric rubber material which, unlike commercial rubber materials, would be recyclable. The chemistry used to make this new material also would allow for the rubbery properties to be turned on and off using electricity. The result of a successful project would be a material that could be converted from a liquid to a rubber at the flip of a switch. Additionally, these materials could be designed to display a color that indicates whether the material is rubbery or not. The color would change when the material has been chemically, electrically, or mechanically weakened to provide a visual warning that the material may not work as expected. This new class of materials could enable new technologies such as electrically controlled rubbers for use in advanced vibration/impact damping systems or in gaskets that change color when in need of replacement.

Beyond potentially enabling new technologies, the pursuit of this research will allow for advanced research training of up to 20 undergraduate students over three years. It will also expand the materials research infrastructure at Appalachian State University, enabling faculty there to continue materials research for years to come.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

In this research project, 2,2'-bipyridine-terminated poly(dimethylsiloxane) (PDMS) chains will be synthesized and blended with various metal salts (e.g. iron (II) chloride) to create metal coordination complex crosslinked polymer networks (MC3PN)'s. These MC3PN's will subsequently be characterized with UV/Vis spectroscopy, cyclic voltammetry, differential scanning calorimetry, and dynamic mechanical analysis to better understand the relationship between the molecular structure and the resulting properties. In the course of the proposed research, the answers to the following five questions will be sought. 1) Is the metal-ligand binding sufficiently stable to serve as crosslinks and impart the MC3PN with elastomeric properties at room temperature? 2) Can altering the network structure (e.g. cross-link density) be used to tailor the mechanical properties of the elastomeric MC3PNs in the same manner that conventional covalently crosslinked elastomer properties (e.g. stiffness and strength) can be tailored? 3) Can the metal coordination complexes be reversibly and controllably un-crosslinked through the introduction of chelating ligands, redox processes, or a change in temperature? 4) Can the color imparted to the MC3PNs by the metal coordination complexes be used to ascertain the degree to which the material is crosslinked and from this to infer the mechanical properties (such as impending failure of the material)? 5) Can the self-assembly of metal coordination complexes impart self-healing properties to the elastomeric material?

Beyond potentially enabling new technologies, the pursuit of this research will allow for advanced research training of up to 20 undergraduate students over three years. It will also expand the materials research infrastructure at Appalachian State University, enabling faculty there to continue materials research for years to come.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to explore new elastomeric materials (rubbers) through the introduction of crosslinks based on labile metal-ligand coordination bonds. Traditionally, the mechanical and thermal stability of rubber is enhanced by covalent crosslinks between polymer chains. However, these crosslinks preclude easy recycling and lock in a single conformation of the material.

In this work we explored bipyridine-terminated poly(dimethylsiloxane) polymer chains held together by iron(II) ions. The introduction of ferrous ion led to gelation of the liquid polymer, forming a rubbery elastomeric network. The polymer chain length, the ratio of metal to bipyridine ligand, and the nature of the metal ion were varied; with the influence on the mechanical properties assessed. In all cases, an elastomer could be prepared by mixing ferrous ion with the bipyridine terminated polymer. In the cases of short chain polymers, the shear storage modulus proved much greater than predicted by theory. X-ray scattering demonstrated microphase separation within these materials, which is the likely cause for the anomalous stiffness. With longer polymer chains (i.e. a greater distance between ionic metal centers in the network) such phase separation was not apparent and the networks behaved similarly to predictions for a traditional, covalently crosslinked elastomer. The mechanical strength of these networks was greatest when the ferrous ion was present at close to the predicted 1:3 stoichiometric ratio.

Thermal studies revealed a reversible rubber-to-liquid transition near 130 oC, likely due to decomposition of the iron bipyridine crosslinks. At lower temperatures (up to approximately 90 oC), heating lead to an increased concentration of these metal centers, presumably by increasing the thermal motion of polymer chain ends, allowing more crosslinks to form. Repeated thermal cycles of melting/gelation of the elastomer could be performed.

By incorporating metal ions within the networks, the resultant elastomers were electrically conductive. Further, electrochemical oxidation of the metal to iron(III) corresponded to decomposition of the network. The application of voltage pulses was suitable to repeatedly decompose/reform the elastomer. Conversely, thin films of the network could be readily deposited by reduction of ferric to ferrous ion. Solution processing conditions for the electrodeposition were optimized.

Taken together, these findings offer the possibility of new material properties in an environmentally responsive material. The individual metal-ligand crosslinks are labile and persist only on a short timescale. However, the strength of the material is ensured by a dynamic network of metal/ligands that form new crosslinks as quickly as other disappear. Such a structural arrangement offers immediate possibilities for a self-healing material. Moreover, the ability to control the physical state of the material based on electrical impulse offers interesting possibilities for haptic displays and other applications.

The project also contributed to the training of a scientifically literate workforce. This work was conducted at a primarily undergraduate institution, with the vast majority of data collection carried out by college undergraduates. Over the funding period, a total of fourteen students participated on the project. Of these, four have already gone on to pursue graduate studies.

Throughout history, the materials used by a civilization have come to define the capabilities and means of subsistence of its people. This has proven true whether the material is stone, iron, or semiconductor. By expanding our understanding of dynamic networks, it is hoped this work will ultimately contribute towards new materials to further advance human technologies.
